subject: Re: [junit] Unit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test ordering
msgSnippet: ... I ve decided that this is actually a question of personal taste. As such, there is no right or wrong answer, at this point. One advantage of dependencies,
messageBody:
On 22/01/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Wouldn't it be nice if the framework told you exactly *which* test failed
> instead of you having to pin down which test starts the Web server or which
> tests opens a JDBC connection among thousands?

I've decided that this is actually a question of personal taste. As
such, there is no right or wrong answer, at this point.

One advantage of dependencies, however, is that you can dramatically
shorten test times if the dependency breaks. For example - if you have
one test that verifies that your remote server deployed correctly, you
don't have to run all of the tests that talk to that server.

The disadvantages of dependencies are real, however. Firstly, I
strongly suspect that only fairly obvious and coarse grain
dependencies will be marked up front. Secondly, developers could
easily mark a dependency that is there by co-incidence, not design -
this would be particularly likely if fixing one test caused another to
start working due to side-effects in the test (e.g. dirty data left
behind). Finally, it encourages tests to have side-effects - this
breaks the strong test isolation principle of JUnit.

(This isn't to say that dependencies are bad - it just says that they
aren't perfect)

My strong preference in this matter would be to use an explicit check
(e.g. in the before test, or before test class, step). Checks or
pre-conditions wouldn't be tests, and they would be easier to isolate
to ensure that they don't cause unexpected side-effects.
